newsitem.title: USA: US safety chief -- "mad cow" focus stays on cattle.
newsitem.headline: US safety chief -- "mad cow" focus stays on cattle.

text.p: The focus of U.S. efforts to prevent a "mad cow" outbreak in the United States will remain on cattle unless there is compelling evidence for a change, the U.S. meat safety chief said Thursday.
Tom Billy, head of the Food Safety and Inspection Service, said scientific reasearch so far found no reason to suspect a risk of a "mad pig" version of bovine spongiform encephalopathy.
Nine union and consumer groups wrote to Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman earlier in the day, asking for more surveillance of pigs.
"At this point in time, there is no known occurrence of TSE (transmissible spongiform encephalopathy) in pigs," Billy told Reuters.
"Given the scientific evidence available to us, our current plan is to focus our efforts on the risk of BSE in cattle," Billy said, including a larger monitoring program.
"If there's new scientific evidence that we become aware of...we are very open to changing our current priorities."

The consumer and union groups said a 1979 tissue sample from one pig sent to market in New York state showed similarities with TSE. Billy said an internal examination of that sample and five others by the Agriculture Department and outside review by two experts did not find any signs of the abnormal prions associated with BSE.
